instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
Hi, i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with issues on the audio Jack. The jack itself and the board look pristine.

The jack only works before playing any audio (if i plug it after playing something it will not detect). If i close/open the lid it is detected again. The audio has a ton shit of noise. The jack is receiving 3.3v. Also tried another OS installation.

I compared the diode mode on the data pins with a good working motherboard of the exact model and i got this:

                                             Good Board                /              Bad Board

<SIGNAL>AUD_CONNJ1_TIP</SIGNAL>:             0.592     /                                     0.753
<SIGNAL>AUD_CONNJ1_TIPDET</SIGNAL>:      0.596      /                                    0.754
<SIGNAL>AUD_CONNJ1_RING</SIGNAL>:         0.599       /                                   0.755
<SIGNAL>AUD_SPDIF_OUT</SIGNAL>:              0.6           /                                    0.6

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
Do you note to have the red light on inside the jack?
Usually bad contacts; check Youtube about how to clean it.
Remove <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
Red light is not on with headphones unplugged. 

Cleaned the jack with contact cleaner and alcohol. 

Removed <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR> no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: I have a somewhat similar issue on a nightmare-ish 3115 (jack not detected when hot plugged, need to put the machine to sleep then it is detected but with heavy distortion on the headphones, speakers work fine) but with heavy liquid damage. Haven't solved it yet, I'll come back at it in a while. Voltage measurements showed some discrepencies compared to a known good board on the audio jack analog outputs, one of them is also used for jack detection when shorted to one jack detect line IIRC. In my case the jack itself looks fine (and static resistance/diode mode measurements look fine too) and replacing the audio codec IC didn't make any difference. Will keep you updated if I get more info on this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Check if macOS detects when you connect headphones; look at output devices.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
Here are some additional notes about my board if it can help you:

Liquid damage on at least a third of the board, all over the edge near display (on both sides but mostly underside), some around PCH, some other parts affected like <TRANSISTOR>Q7840</TRANSISTOR> and a bit around audio codec IC, lots of damaged parts and a several burnt vias. Almost fully working but the audio jack… Internal speakers work fine. Headphones won't get detected unless I put the machine to sleep and wake it up. But headphone output is distorted, more on the left channel btw. It "pops" when audio codec wakes up/goes to sleep, pretty much when DC gets sent out. Sure enough, it looks like there's 2VDC on both channels. Replaced the audio codec IC, same thing. There's also 2VDC on HPREF, which I assume is what causes 2VDC on the output. I thought it may have been caused by <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> so I removed it, same thing. I cut the trace just before TP[1]<SIGNAL>HPAMP_REF</SIGNAL> to isolate the audio codec IC, I now have 3V on the audio codec IC HPREF pin and 0V on the rest of the line. Now it's stuck in optical out. Previously L6400 was missing which caused <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> to pull the SDA line low but that's been taken care of.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Yes, its recognizes the headphones but only in the situations i explained it works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
When sounds no good, can you still see macOS switching correctly headphones/speakers?
Just in case, disconnect BIL and check if the issue is still present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
macOS will only switch to headphones when i start playing the audio (not when connecting), and after i disconnect it goes back to speakers. 

If i reconnect without turning off/closing the lid the headphones wont work and it wont switch from speakers either. 

Disconnected BIL same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Inspect the components from pages 61/62.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Everything looks as good as new

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
[QUOTE="piernov, post: 71568, member: 1057"]
Here are some additional notes about my board if it can help you:

Liquid damage on at least a third of the board, all over the edge near display (on both sides but mostly underside), some around PCH, some other parts affected like <TRANSISTOR>Q7840</TRANSISTOR> and a bit around audio codec IC, lots of damaged parts and a several burnt vias. Almost fully working but the audio jack… Internal speakers work fine. Headphones won't get detected unless I put the machine to sleep and wake it up. But headphone output is distorted, more on the left channel btw. It "pops" when audio codec wakes up/goes to sleep, pretty much when DC gets sent out. Sure enough, it looks like there's 2VDC on both channels. Replaced the audio codec IC, same thing. There's also 2VDC on HPREF, which I assume is what causes 2VDC on the output. I thought it may have been caused by <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> so I removed it, same thing. I cut the trace just before TP[1]<SIGNAL>HPAMP_REF</SIGNAL> to isolate the audio codec IC, I now have 3V on the audio codec IC HPREF pin and 0V on the rest of the line. Now it's stuck in optical out. Previously L6400 was missing which caused <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> to pull the SDA line low but that's been taken care of.
[/QUOTE]
Thank you very much for your help. Im trying to understand it but im relatively new to this.

Yeah, mine pops too when connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Changed the audio IC just because, but made no difference.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Changed the audio jack also, but to no effect. Do you have any more guidance? Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Tried PRAM reset?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Yes, several times.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
"Changed the audio IC"
<CHIP>U6201</CHIP>?
Check if all its power rails have correct voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message:
Yes, <CHIP>U6201</CHIP> was replaced. 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8R1V5_S0_AUDIO_DIG</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP4V5_AUDIO_ANALOG</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>

All are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: In my case replacing <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> seems to have fixed the problem. <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> is involved with the bias circuit and <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> was corroded. I think <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> was actually the culprit but since I missed the corroded <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> at first I replaced it at the same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Do you think <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> was corroded too? Since its so close to C405.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: It was looking ok under it but it may have gotten damaged anyway. Board was already cleaned in USC before I got it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Audio Jack Issues
threads.message: Replaced bot still same issue.
